Mashed Yams with Butter

Jump to Recipe

If you're looking for a delicious and comforting side dish, look no further than mashed yams with butter. This classic recipe transforms simple yams into a creamy, flavorful delight that pairs perfectly with any meal. Yams are not only scrumptious but also packed with nutrients, making them a wonderful addition to your diet. In this easy-to-follow recipe, you'll learn how to create perfectly mashed yams that are rich in flavor and texture. With just a few ingredients - large yams, butter, salt, and a hint of black pepper - you can whip up a side dish thatâ€™s sure to please your family and friends. Whether you're preparing for a holiday feast or a casual dinner, mashed yams are a versatile choice that everyone will love. Ready to elevate your culinary skills? Let's dive into this simple yet satisfying mashed yams recipe!

Ingredients

yams

Choose firm, smooth yams with no bruises or soft spots. For a sweeter flavor, consider using sweet potatoes instead, as they have a similar texture but a sweeter taste. You can also roast the yams before mashing them to enhance their natural sweetness and depth of flavor.

butter

Use unsalted butter to control the saltiness of your dish. For a richer flavor, try using European-style butter, which has a higher fat content. If you're looking for a dairy-free alternative, coconut oil or vegan butter can work well.

salt

Start with a smaller amount and adjust to taste, since different brands of salt have varying levels of saltiness. Sea salt or kosher salt can add a different texture and flavor profile compared to table salt.

black pepper

Freshly ground black pepper will provide the best flavor. If you want to add a bit of heat, consider using white pepper instead, which has a milder but more pungent flavor.

milk (optional)

If you want a creamier texture, whole milk is ideal; however, you can use half-and-half or heavy cream for even more richness. For a dairy-free option, almond milk, oat milk, or any plant-based milk can be used, but be mindful of the flavor they may add.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Prepare the Yams

    Begin by peeling the 2 large yams using a vegetable peeler. Make sure to remove all the skin, as it can be tough and unpalatable in the final dish. Once peeled, cut the yams into uniform chunks, about 1-2 inches in size. This ensures even cooking.

  • Step 2: Cook the Yams

    Place the yam chunks into a large pot and cover them with water. Make sure thereâ€™s at least an inch of water above the yams to prevent boiling dry. Bring the water to a boil over high heat, then reduce to a simmer. Cook for approximately 15-20 minutes, or until you can easily pierce the yams with a fork. This step is crucial for achieving the right texture.

  • Step 3: Drain and Return to Pot

    Once the yams are tender, carefully drain them in a colander to remove the hot water. Return the drained yams back to the pot. This allows any excess moisture to evaporate, which helps the final mash to be creamier.

  • Step 4: Add Butter and Seasoning

    Add 4 tablespoons of butter to the warm yams, along with 1 teaspoon of salt and black pepper to taste. The warmth of the yams will melt the butter, making it easier to mix in.

  • Step 5: Mash the Yams

    Using a potato masher or a fork, begin mashing the yams until they reach your desired consistency. For a smoother texture, consider using a hand mixer. If you prefer a creamier mash, slowly incorporate 1/4 cup of milk while mashing. Adjust the amount of milk based on your preference.

  • Step 6: Taste and Adjust Seasoning

    After mashing, taste your mashed yams and adjust the seasoning as needed. You can add more salt, pepper, or even more butter for richness. This step is important, as it allows you to customize the flavor according to your taste.

Frequently Asked Questions

How do I peel and cut yams correctly?

To peel yams, use a vegetable peeler or a knife to remove the skin. Cut them into even-sized chunks (about 1-2 inches) to ensure they cook evenly.

How can I tell when yams are tender?

Yams are tender when you can easily pierce them with a fork. This typically takes about 15-20 minutes of boiling.

Is it necessary to add milk to mashed yams?

Adding milk is optional. If you prefer a creamier texture, add about 1/4 cup of milk. You can adjust this based on your preference.

What should I do if my mashed yams are too dry?

If your mashed yams are too dry, you can add more butter or a little more milk to achieve your desired consistency.

How can I ensure my mashed yams are seasoned well?

Start with the recommended amount of salt (1 teaspoon) and black pepper. After mashing, taste your yams and adjust the seasoning as needed. Remember, you can always add more, but you can't take it out!

What if I don't have a potato masher?

If you don't have a potato masher, you can use a fork or even a hand mixer to mash the yams until smooth.

Are there any tips for kitchen safety while cooking?

Always use a cutting board when chopping to protect your countertops and keep your fingers safe. Be careful with hot pots and boiling water; use oven mitts when handling them.

Can I add other ingredients to my mashed yams?

Absolutely! You can mix in ingredients like garlic, herbs, or spices to enhance flavor. Experiment to find what you like best!

How should I store leftover mashed yams?

Store leftover mashed yams in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 3-5 days. Reheat in the microwave or on the stove, adding a little butter or milk if they seem dry.

What is the best way to serve mashed yams?

Mashed yams can be served as a side dish to complement proteins like chicken, turkey, or fish. They also pair well with roasted vegetables.

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

This dish is naturally gluten-free and vegetarian. For a dairy-free option, substitute the butter with a plant-based butter or olive oil, and replace milk with almond milk or coconut milk. If you're looking to reduce sugar intake, consider using less butter or pairing with a protein that balances the sweetness of the yams.

Pairings

Mashed yams pair beautifully with roasted meats such as turkey, chicken, or pork. For a vegetarian option, consider serving with grilled vegetables or a hearty lentil loaf. In terms of beverages, a light-bodied white wine like Sauvignon Blanc or a refreshing apple cider complements the dish's sweetness. For a non-alcoholic option, a ginger ale with a splash of lemon works well.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the mashed yams in a warm bowl, garnished with a sprinkle of fresh herbs like chives or parsley for added color and flavor. For a festive touch, drizzle a little extra melted butter on top and add a few toasted pecans or walnuts for crunch. This dish can be served family-style or plated individually for a more formal setting. Be sure to serve hot, as the warmth enhances the buttery, sweet flavor of the yams.

Mashed Yams with Butter

$5
200 kcal
Difficulty: 15%
Servings: 4

Description

Creamy, buttery mashed yams that are smooth, sweet, and comforting.

Ingredients

  • yams: 2 large
  • butter: 4 tablespoons
  • salt: 1 teaspoon
  • black pepper: to taste
  • milk (optional): 1/4 cup
